original_title: Sri Lanka’s stocks edge up on a 18 month high on banking and tourism sectors
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka shares close up on an 18th month high on Wednesday after buying interest was channeled on clarity the banking sector on debt restructuring and tourism as July produces favorable arrivals for July, an analyst said.

The main All Share Price Index was up 0.53 percent or 60.11 points to 11,446.83, this is the highest the market has been since February 28, while S&P SL20 was up 0.35 percent or 11.47 points to 3,321.06.
“Buying interest was seen in blue chip counters and the banking sector, because concerns have been lifted with regard to debt optimization and macroeconomic factors,” an analyst said.

Sri Lanka has seen a revival in tourism as the island nation recorded 143, 039 tourist arrivals for July, the highest monthly arrivals recorded for the year, data from the Tourism Development Authority showed.
In the first seven months, Sri Lanka welcomed 767, 913 visitors, compared to 719, 978 in the previous year.
India accounted as the top tourist traffic generator accumulating 16 percent of the total arrivals.

The market generated a turnover of 3.8 billion rupees, majority of the revenue came in from the banking sector bringing in 1.4 billion rupees, while the capital sector brought in 945 million rupees and the diversified financials sector brought in 432 million rupees, while the yearly average stands at 1.7 billion rupees.
The market generated a net foreign inflow of 323 million rupees.
Sri Lanka’s announced domestic debt restructuring plan has avoided adding to the “fragility” of the banking system, World bank Country Director Faris Hadad-Zervos said.
Sri Lanka kept banks, which have already been hit by bad loans and mark-to-market losses out of re-structuring plan.
Sri Lanka’s consumer price inflation fell to 6.3 percent in 12-months to July 2023, with food prices deflating 1.4 percent over the year, data from the state statistics office showed.
More than 94 percent of remaining holders of dollar denominated Sri Lanka Development Bond holders have agreed to exchange for longer term rupee bonds, a government statement said.
Out of 837.5 million dollars of remaining SLDBs, owners of 791.4 million dollars of bonds have offered to exchange and the offer has been accepted, the Finance Ministry said.
Of that 814.83 million was from institutional investors. Without individuals, 97.13 percent of holders have accepted the offer. With individuals, 94.49 percent have accepted the offer.
Gainers during trade were Commercial Bank, DFCC Bank and National Development Bank.
